thread.title: Buyers circle Jimmy's Iced Coffee as turnover tops £2m
thread.title_full: Buyers circle Jimmy's Iced Coffee as turnover tops £2m

title: Buyers circle Jimmy's Iced Coffee as turnover tops £2m
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 5, 2015, 20:48 BST - UK Markets closed Buyers circle Jimmy's Iced Coffee as turnover tops £2m By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 8 minutes ago 2.497 +0.080 
The start-up has bounced back from its manufacturing nightmares this summer to secure a further supermarket listing 
Jimmy’s Iced Coffee, a start-up launched out of a bedsit by a brother and sister duo , has received a takeover offer from a major drinks company after landing a distribution deal with Sainsbury’s. 
The company, which sells ready-made iced coffees in a range of flavours, is already stocked in Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) and Waitrose, and generated £1.2m in revenue last year. 
The Sainsbury’s deal is expected to take turnover to £2m, and its founders Susie and Jimmy Cregan claim that the rapid growth of the business has made it a takeover target. “We have had interest from the third largest drinks company in the world for an acquisition or possible distribution deal,” said Mr Cregan, while compering the recent Virgin StartUp Foodpreneur event in London. 
“This is something we are considering in the best interests of the business to access further distribution.” 
The company experienced production issues during the summer, when a machine broke down at its manufacturing facility, resulting in a two-month wait for products at a cost of £50,000. “We had to short all our customers at peak season, which was horrible,” said Ms Cregan. 
However, it has quickly bounced back and has started exporting its wares.The first shipment hit shelves in Hong Kong a few days ago. It is poised to launch its winter bestseller , a mocha iced coffee, which has been placed by Tesco at the front of 1,300 supermarkets. Tesco has also just accepted its slim can into its Meal Deal offering, which the Cregans predict will drive a 60pc increase in sales. 
In recent years, small suppliers have complained of Tesco’s tough payment terms but the founders say their deal with the grocery giant is “superb”. 
"They were very supportive during [the manufacturing issue] and ensured shelves were restocked to their fullest when we received stock again,” says Ms Cregan. 
The pair borrowed £140,000 from their parents to start Jimmy’s Iced Coffee and owed their production facility £250,000, but the company is now debt free 
If the acquisition deal goes ahead, the siblings plan to stay with the business and “do all the fun entrepreneurial stuff”, Ms Cregan said, adding that their ambitions were still focused on the start-up. “We want to be in every fridge, in the travel and convenience sector, across the globe."
